items.description: The percentage of alcohol in a beverage.
A drink served before a meal to stimulate appetite.
Highly concentrated alcoholic infusions flavored with herbs, spices, or roots.
To make a drink directly in the serving glass without shaking or stirring separately.
To cool a glass or liquid, usually with ice.
A mixed alcoholic drink made with spirits and other ingredients.
A very small amount of liquid, usually bitters (approx. a few drops).
Water added to a drink through melting ice during shaking or stirring.
To gently pour an ingredient on top of a drink so it remains layered.
Indicates freshly squeezed juice rather than bottled.
A decorative or aromatic element added to a drink (e.g., citrus peel, olive).
A tall drink made with a spirit and a larger proportion of mixer.
A spirit flavored by soaking ingredients such as fruits, herbs, or spices.
A measuring tool used to pour precise amounts of liquid.
Pouring liquids of different densities to create visible layers.
To gently crush ingredients to release flavors (usually herbs or fruit).
A non-alcoholic ingredient added to a spirit (e.g., soda, tonic, juice).
A spirit served alone, without ice or mixers.
A drink served over ice.
A measure of alcohol strength (mostly used in the U.S.).
A shared mixed drink, traditionally served in a large bowl.
To mix ingredients vigorously with ice using a shaker.
A small-volume cocktail, usually spirit-forward.
A cocktail style with spirit, citrus juice, and sweetener.
To gently mix ingredients with ice, usually for clear drinks.
To separate liquid from ice or solids when pouring.
To finish a drink by adding a mixer or sparkling ingredient.
A drink served chilled but without ice in the glass.
A cocktail made with the house (non-premium) spirits.
